RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the border patrol agents: Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass

RESOLVED_ENTITIES.experienced officers: Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.a Border Patrol agent: Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.law enforcement officers: Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Michael Brett Jacquinot: Defendant convicted for possession with intent to distribute marijuana, who entered a conditional plea of guilty and was sentenced to 46 months' imprisonment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Andrew P. Graham: Border Patrol Agent with three years' experience serving in the Alpine area, testified about the driver's behavior contributing to reasonable suspicion, involved in at least 30 narcotics cases and 15 to 20 alien smuggling cases
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jay Snodgrass: Border Patrol Agent with eleven years' experience, including a few months in the Alpine area, contributed to the determination of suspicious activity, author of a memo regarding the defendant's case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass: Border Patrol Agents involved in surveillance near the United States/Mexican border, providing reasonable suspicion for a stop based on proximity to the border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Brignoni-Ponce Jacquinot: Defendant in a drug trafficking case, exhibited suspicious behavior while driving, sole passenger in the truck, found with 286.44 pounds of marijuana and two unloaded handguns, argues against the suspicion of the truck's behavior, contested the application of a two-level upward adjustment for possession of a weapon
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.ROBERT M. PARKER: Circuit Judge, author of a special concurring opinion regarding the absurdity of jurisprudence related to the southern border area of Texas, expressing hope for a return to reason in drug-related cases
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Judge Wiener: author of a dissent highlighting the absurdity of jurisprudence related to the southern border area of Texas
